div.span: can i ask you a technical angular question?
we're making the entire app angular, login page and all, because of the complexities posed by protractor
we'll have to be able to login as multiple users and so that means logging out into the currently un-angular app
and so, everything will be angular
but that means, from my understanding, we're moving authentication largely into angular
no, i mean does that make sense, the last bit?
we use passport, i don't think oauth
oauth seems to be a different module you have to install, so i'm guessing it's not that
so i'm thinking what happens is we serve the app – index.handlebars or whatever, statically
and the rest of it, we make a service that checks with passport about whether the user is authenticated
and so instead of what we have right now

message.div: if you use cookies, though, you don't need to make that service
the cookies are placed on the header of every request

div.span: we do, we use sessiontokens or whtever

message.div: i wanted to use this but we don't use tokens
you might just serve up the angular directly
and then have a run block always checking the authentication status

div.span: sorry, what do you mean by serving angular directly?
i'm going to directly serve a page with angular app in it
you don't know if ng-token-auth will work with passport?
seems like it's meant to replaceit
i guess it would make sense to do if that's what we're moving toward....
Session support using cookies or localStorage
ok! will give it a go. thank you

cause she has very particular ideas about how things should be and i've gotten in trouble before for doing something else
don't want to have a conversation with her right now about how wrong i am ;/

div.span: i have an angular routing question!
so, i'm moving all of our app, including login, into angular, right?
the thought is, i think i need to have a / page that serves the app (ng-app) statically first
and then have that page include a link to the angular login
erm basically i'm trying to have it be so that every time you hit '/', you're rerouted to the angular '#/login'
so i don't need a link
i just need to write a route '/' (express), that checks if you're logged in
and then angular will take care of either letting you into the app or loading the login page
it'll tell me whether i'm logged in
and you know how right now we statically render the index page with a bunch of config files?
so i think i'll need to get angular to make a request from the server for it
and have it reload the index page again or something
if you're logged in, reload index
if not, go back to '/', get '#/login'
which is pretty much what's happening right now, i think, but yeah

message.div: and the only thing to add is that you need to verify login with a Session Service
if so, then it doesn't matter

div.span: get that they're executed first thing
so i guess i get them
so i guess i don't need an interceptor

message.div: just think of them as an onLoaded callback
except for angular that's not a full pageload

div.span: except is there a weird ajax asynchronicity with it?
i think i saw somewhere that by the time ng realizes user is not logged in, it'll already have flashed the logged in state page
which is, i think, why people use http interceptor

message.div: i thought that .run blocks happen when the page loads, but the angular partials havent'

div.span: yesterday we were talknig about ui named views in tabs and i was asking why it's easier to do that than states

message.div: i mentioned that, but I don't think we actually spoke about it
doing sticky-states will give you the proper URL
cause users can navigate through history and such like they'd expect
but using named views is way easier
and you can just use the angular bootstrap-ui tabs for everything

div.span: also, thanks for the ui stuff
i think our goal is to have working urls
so we're probably going to stay away from views when it comes to the buttons
and inside of that could be views

message.div: yeah — that might be easiest when you start adding all that functionality into those states
